values.description:
Added Frustum class. This is a basic implementation of a [view frustum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frustum).

This is part of the swarm project, so no need to review this for Gazebo6 release. 

The frustum will be used to compute objects that are within a camera without using a rendering engine.
values.title: Frustum

summary.raw:
Added Frustum class. This is a basic implementation of a [view frustum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frustum).

This is part of the swarm project, so no need to review this for Gazebo6 release. 

The frustum will be used to compute objects that are within a camera without using a rendering engine.
summary.html:
Added Frustum class. This is a basic implementation of a view frustum.

This is part of the swarm project, so no need to review this for Gazebo6 release.

The frustum will be used to compute objects that are within a camera without using a rendering engine.

values.description:
The frustum planes had an assumption of being oriented at the origin.

Easiest way to reproduce the problem:

1. Use gazebo6 debians

1. Run [this world](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/ignitionrobotics/kMkAM)

1. Place a shape at the origin.

1. Rotate the box with logical camera sensor so that it faces the shape at the origin.

1. In a terminal: `gz topic -e /gazebo/default/box/linlogical_camera/models`
values.title: Fix frustum planes

summary.raw:
The frustum planes had an assumption of being oriented at the origin.

Easiest way to reproduce the problem:

1. Use gazebo6 debians

1. Run [this world](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/ignitionrobotics/kMkAM)

1. Place a shape at the origin.

1. Rotate the box with logical camera sensor so that it faces the shape at the origin.

1. In a terminal: `gz topic -e /gazebo/default/box/linlogical_camera/models`
summary.html:
The frustum planes had an assumption of being oriented at the origin.

Easiest way to reproduce the problem:

  1. Use gazebo6 debians

  2. Run this world

  3. Place a shape at the origin.

  4. Rotate the box with logical camera sensor so that it faces the shape at the origin.

  5. In a terminal: gz topic -e /gazebo/default/box/linlogical_camera/models

values.description:
When building on i686 without SSE, the ign equality helper uses the extra
precision within the x87 floating point module when comparing the difference
between the two arguments to the epsilon value.  This causes the
Line2Test.CollinearPoint unit test to fail when epsilon is set to .0001

```
13/44 Testing: UNIT_Line2_TEST
13/44 Test: UNIT_Line2_TEST
Command: "/builddir/build/BUILD/ignition-math2-2.2.2/build/src/UNIT_Line2_TEST" "--gtest_output=xml:/builddir/build/BUILD/ignition-math2-2.2.2/build/test_results/UNIT_Line2_TEST.xml"
Directory: /builddir/build/BUILD/ignition-math2-2.2.2/build/src
"UNIT_Line2_TEST" start time: Aug 21 00:43 UTC
Output:
----------------------------------------------------------
Running main() from gtest_main.cc
[==========] Running 9 tests from 1 test case.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 9 tests from Line2Test
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.Constructor
[       OK ] Line2Test.Constructor (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.Length
[       OK ] Line2Test.Length (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.Slope
[       OK ] Line2Test.Slope (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.ParallelLine
[       OK ] Line2Test.ParallelLine (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.CollinearLine
[       OK ] Line2Test.CollinearLine (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.CollinearPoint
/builddir/build/BUILD/ignition-math2-2.2.2/src/Line2_TEST.cc:152: Failure
Value of: lineA.Collinear(pt, 1e-4)
  Actual: false
Expected: true
/builddir/build/BUILD/ignition-math2-2.2.2/src/Line2_TEST.cc:164: Failure
Value of: lineA.Collinear(pt, 1e-4)
  Actual: false
Expected: true
[  FAILED  ] Line2Test.CollinearPoint (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.Intersect
[       OK ] Line2Test.Intersect (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.Equality
[       OK ] Line2Test.Equality (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Line2Test.OperatorStreamOut
[       OK ] Line2Test.OperatorStreamOut (0 ms)
[----------] 9 tests from Line2Test (0 ms total)
[----------] Global test environment tear-down
[==========] 9 tests from 1 test case ran. (0 ms total)
[  PASSED  ] 8 tests.
[  FAILED  ] 1 test, listed below:
[  FAILED  ] Line2Test.CollinearPoint
 1 FAILED TEST
<end of output>
Test time =   0.00 sec
----------------------------------------------------------
Test Failed.
"UNIT_Line2_TEST" end time: Aug 21 00:43 UTC
"UNIT_Line2_TEST" time elapsed: 00:00:00
----------------------------------------------------------
```

This patch creates an intermediate value for the difference between the two
arguments to be compared, which gets rid of the extra x87 precision. The
resulting comparison is then performed without the extra precision, allowing
the test to pass.

This test was performed against ignition-math2-2.2.2

See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16325277/floating-point-equality-test-and-extra-precision-can-this-code-fail for a discussion of x87 equality pitfalls.
values.title: Change equality helper to work with 387 fp unit

values.description:
In Windows find_package(package) finds the PackageConfig.cmake following
a set of path patterns [1]:
~~~
<prefix>/                                               (W)
<prefix>/(cmake|CMake)/                                 (W)
<prefix>/<name>*/                                       (W)
<prefix>/<name>*/(cmake|CMake)/                         (W)
~~~

This commit modifies the CMake config installation to install
them in CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX/CMake (see for reference [2]).

Furthermore it modifies the PROJECT_NAME to match the CMake package
name, so the default CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX will be
C:/Program Files/ignition-math{MAJOR_VERSION} and any CMake package
will then be able (in case the CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX is not changed)
to find the ign-math library by a  find_package(ignition-math{MAJOR_VERSION})
cmake command, without any need of specific enviromental variables
or cmake variables.


[1] : http://www.cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/command/find_package.html

[2] : https://github.com/robotology/ycm/blob/master/modules/InstallBasicPackageFiles.cmake#L175
values.title: Fix logic of installation of CMake configuration files in Windows

summary.raw:
In Windows find_package(package) finds the PackageConfig.cmake following
a set of path patterns [1]:
~~~
<prefix>/                                               (W)
<prefix>/(cmake|CMake)/                                 (W)
<prefix>/<name>*/                                       (W)
<prefix>/<name>*/(cmake|CMake)/                         (W)
~~~

This commit modifies the CMake config installation to install
them in CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX/CMake (see for reference [2]).

Furthermore it modifies the PROJECT_NAME to match the CMake package
name, so the default CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX will be
C:/Program Files/ignition-math{MAJOR_VERSION} and any CMake package
will then be able (in case the CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX is not changed)
to find the ign-math library by a  find_package(ignition-math{MAJOR_VERSION})
cmake command, without any need of specific enviromental variables
or cmake variables.


[1] : http://www.cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/command/find_package.html

[2] : https://github.com/robotology/ycm/blob/master/modules/InstallBasicPackageFiles.cmake#L175
summary.html:
In Windows find_package(package) finds the PackageConfig.cmake following a set of path patterns [1]:

<prefix>/                                               (W)
<prefix>/(cmake|CMake)/                                 (W)
<prefix>/<name>*/                                       (W)
<prefix>/<name>*/(cmake|CMake)/                         (W)

This commit modifies the CMake config installation to install them in CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX/CMake (see for reference [2]).

Furthermore it modifies the PROJECT_NAME to match the CMake package name, so the default CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX will be C:/Program Files/ignition-math{MAJOR_VERSION} and any CMake package will then be able (in case the CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX is not changed) to find the ign-math library by a find_package(ignition-math{MAJOR_VERSION}) cmake command, without any need of specific enviromental variables or cmake variables.

[1] : http://www.cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/command/find_package.html

[2] : https://github.com/robotology/ycm/blob/master/modules/InstallBasicPackageFiles.cmake#L175

values.description:
FrameGraph instances allow to:

- add a frame (with name, pose and a parent frame)
- remove frame
- change the pose of a frame
- get the pose of a frame expressed in another frame

values.description:
Classes to manage transformation in a tree structure where each frame element has a parent, a pose and unique children. Features:

* Change the local pose of frame elements
* Get a transformation between 2 frames

  • Get a transformation between 2 frames

values.description:
Change of the CMake infrastructure to export a relocatable CMake package.

The library is now used in downstream packages as an imported target
(see https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/manual/cmake-buildsystem.7.html#imported-targets).

This means there is now no need to manually set include directories, link directories and
compiler flags in packages using ignition-math, but it is sufficient to just link
to the imported target, as it is possible to see in the examples directory.

@\_jrivero\_  I don't know if you are already preparing a more systematic migration to relocatable cmake packages, for example starting from ign-seed or ign-cmake . In that case feel free to decline this pull request.
values.title: Migrate to relocatable CMake package

summary.raw:
Change of the CMake infrastructure to export a relocatable CMake package.

The library is now used in downstream packages as an imported target
(see https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/manual/cmake-buildsystem.7.html#imported-targets).

This means there is now no need to manually set include directories, link directories and
compiler flags in packages using ignition-math, but it is sufficient to just link
to the imported target, as it is possible to see in the examples directory.

@\_jrivero\_  I don't know if you are already preparing a more systematic migration to relocatable cmake packages, for example starting from ign-seed or ign-cmake . In that case feel free to decline this pull request.
summary.html:
Change of the CMake infrastructure to export a relocatable CMake package.

The library is now used in downstream packages as an imported target (see https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/manual/cmake-buildsystem.7.html#imported-targets).

This means there is now no need to manually set include directories, link directories and compiler flags in packages using ignition-math, but it is sufficient to just link to the imported target, as it is possible to see in the examples directory.

@_jrivero_ I don't know if you are already preparing a more systematic migration to relocatable cmake packages, for example starting from ign-seed or ign-cmake . In that case feel free to decline this pull request.

values.description:
I noticed that not all the Vector and Matrix classes had the same types of multiplication operators (left/right for scalar, vector, and possibly matrix). I think the changes are well-described by the new documentation and are covered by new testing code added here.

* https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/307 is happy
values.title: Multiplication improvements for Vector/Matrix classes

values.description:
The [ign-math2 branch fails on windows7](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/sw_ignition/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/11/), though [default works fine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/sw_ignition/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/10/). This backports some fixes from default so `ign-math2` will work.

[jenkins windows7 build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/sw_ignition/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/13/) is fixed

values.description:
Many math classes have `==` operators overloaded that use the `math::equal` helper function with a hard-coded tolerance. This PR adds an Equal function to the `Matrix[34]` and `Vector[234]` classes that takes an additional argument for numerical tolerance. I modified the `==` operator to use this functions with the tolerance specified explicitly. All these classes use `1e-6`, except for `Vector3`, which uses `1e-3`.

[drone is happy](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/345)
values.title: Add Equal function with numerical tolerance argument

summary.raw:
Many math classes have `==` operators overloaded that use the `math::equal` helper function with a hard-coded tolerance. This PR adds an Equal function to the `Matrix[34]` and `Vector[234]` classes that takes an additional argument for numerical tolerance. I modified the `==` operator to use this functions with the tolerance specified explicitly. All these classes use `1e-6`, except for `Vector3`, which uses `1e-3`.

[drone is happy](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/345)
summary.html:
Many math classes have == operators overloaded that use the math::equal helper function with a hard-coded tolerance. This PR adds an Equal function to the Matrix[34] and Vector[234] classes that takes an additional argument for numerical tolerance. I modified the == operator to use this functions with the tolerance specified explicitly. All these classes use 1e-6, except for Vector3, which uses 1e-3.

drone is happy

values.description:
pull request #67 increased the minimum cmake version requirement to 2.8.11, but this is actually not high enough (see this [drone build failure](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/357), which used [this ppa](https://launchpad.net/~kalakris/+archive/ubuntu/cmake)).

With this pull request and [a more recent ppa](https://launchpad.net/~smspillaz/+archive/ubuntu/cmake-2.8.12), the [drone build is happy](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/359).
values.title: Require cmake 2.8.12

With this pull request and [a more recent ppa](https://launchpad.net/~smspillaz/+archive/ubuntu/cmake-2.8.12), the [drone build is happy](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/359).

values.description: To enable graphical inertia modification in gazebo (see [design document](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_design/src/b2d3fd8746867/inertia_resize/inertia_resize.md) and [design document pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/28/move-physics-inertial-to-ignition-math-add/diff)) the [gazebo::physics::Inertial](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/f69b82f6e25ce51bac/gazebo/physics/Inertial.hh) is being ported to ignition math. The first step in that process is creating a new sub-class called `MassMatrix3` that contains the scalar mass and the symmetric moment of inertia matrix components. A follow-up pull request will provide functionality for diagonalizing an inertia matrix to identify the principal moments of inertia and orientation of the principal axes. For now, the new class is added with accessors,modifiers and basic operators.
values.title: First part of MassMatrix3 class, mostly accessors and modifiers

summary.raw: To enable graphical inertia modification in gazebo (see [design document](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_design/src/b2d3fd8746867/inertia_resize/inertia_resize.md) and [design document pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/28/move-physics-inertial-to-ignition-math-add/diff)) the [gazebo::physics::Inertial](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/f69b82f6e25ce51bac/gazebo/physics/Inertial.hh) is being ported to ignition math. The first step in that process is creating a new sub-class called `MassMatrix3` that contains the scalar mass and the symmetric moment of inertia matrix components. A follow-up pull request will provide functionality for diagonalizing an inertia matrix to identify the principal moments of inertia and orientation of the principal axes. For now, the new class is added with accessors,modifiers and basic operators.
summary.html: To enable graphical inertia modification in gazebo (see design document and design document pull request) the gazebo::physics::Inertial is being ported to ignition math. The first step in that process is creating a new sub-class called MassMatrix3 that contains the scalar mass and the symmetric moment of inertia matrix components. A follow-up pull request will provide functionality for diagonalizing an inertia matrix to identify the principal moments of inertia and orientation of the principal axes. For now, the new class is added with accessors,modifiers and basic operators.

values.description:
As a follow-up to pull request #77, this adds the `PrincipalMoments` function to the `MassMatrix3` class, which computes the eigenvalues of the moment of inertia matrix using the algorithm described in the following paper:

* [A Method for Fast Diagonalization of a 2x2 or 3x3 Real Symmetric Matrix](http://arxiv.org/abs/1306.6291v4) by Maarten Kronenburg

The next pull request will add a function that computes the rotational offset of the principal axes (based on the rotation of the eigenvectors of the moment of inertia matrix). See [branch mass_matrix](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branches/compare/mass_matrix%0Dign-math2) for a preview.

Note that line 361 has no test coverage because that line should never be reached, but I left the check to be safe and prevent a divide by zero.

I tried to comment the code to match the equations in the paper. It's maybe a little dry, but I'm happy to explain the math/code in person if anyone has any questions. I can also provide an octave script or ipython notebook to verify the eigenvalues of the matrices used in the test.
values.title: MassMatrix3::PrincipalMoments, diagonalizing the moment of inertia matrix

summary.raw:
As a follow-up to pull request #77, this adds the `PrincipalMoments` function to the `MassMatrix3` class, which computes the eigenvalues of the moment of inertia matrix using the algorithm described in the following paper:

* [A Method for Fast Diagonalization of a 2x2 or 3x3 Real Symmetric Matrix](http://arxiv.org/abs/1306.6291v4) by Maarten Kronenburg

The next pull request will add a function that computes the rotational offset of the principal axes (based on the rotation of the eigenvectors of the moment of inertia matrix). See [branch mass_matrix](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branches/compare/mass_matrix%0Dign-math2) for a preview.

Note that line 361 has no test coverage because that line should never be reached, but I left the check to be safe and prevent a divide by zero.

I tried to comment the code to match the equations in the paper. It's maybe a little dry, but I'm happy to explain the math/code in person if anyone has any questions. I can also provide an octave script or ipython notebook to verify the eigenvalues of the matrices used in the test.
summary.html:
As a follow-up to pull request #77, this adds the PrincipalMoments function to the MassMatrix3 class, which computes the eigenvalues of the moment of inertia matrix using the algorithm described in the following paper:

  • A Method for Fast Diagonalization of a 2x2 or 3x3 Real Symmetric Matrix by Maarten Kronenburg

The next pull request will add a function that computes the rotational offset of the principal axes (based on the rotation of the eigenvectors of the moment of inertia matrix). See branch mass_matrix for a preview.

Note that line 361 has no test coverage because that line should never be reached, but I left the check to be safe and prevent a divide by zero.

I tried to comment the code to match the equations in the paper. It's maybe a little dry, but I'm happy to explain the math/code in person if anyone has any questions. I can also provide an octave script or ipython notebook to verify the eigenvalues of the matrices used in the test.

values.description:
Part 3 in a series of pull requests for diagonalizing inertia matrices to identify the principal moments and principal axes (see also pull request #77 and pull request #79). This pull request adds `MassMatrix::PrincipalAxesOffset`, which returns a Quaternion corresponding to the rotational offset of the principal axes. The rotation matrix constructed from this quaternion corresponds to the eigenvectors of the inertia matrix. This function is also based on the following paper:

* [A Method for Fast Diagonalization of a 2x2 or 3x3 Real Symmetric Matrix](http://arxiv.org/abs/1306.6291v4) by Maarten Kronenburg

This function is a bit more complicated than `PrincipalMoments` since there is some logic required to determine the sign of some of the Euler angles. There are quite a few tests, though, that verify the functions by reconstructing the inertia matrix from the principal moments and rotation matrix of eigenvectors.

There is also an ipython notebook included that provides justification for a claim in the section about repeated principal moments. It is viewable here:

* http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/raw/mass_matrix_part3/include/ignition/math/MassMatrix3.ipynb
values.title: MassMatrix::PrincipalAxesOffset (eigenvectors of inertia matrix)

Part 3 in a series of pull requests for diagonalizing inertia matrices to identify the principal moments and principal axes (see also pull request #77 and pull request #79). This pull request adds MassMatrix::PrincipalAxesOffset, which returns a Quaternion corresponding to the rotational offset of the principal axes. The rotation matrix constructed from this quaternion corresponds to the eigenvectors of the inertia matrix. This function is also based on the following paper:

  • A Method for Fast Diagonalization of a 2x2 or 3x3 Real Symmetric Matrix by Maarten Kronenburg

This function is a bit more complicated than PrincipalMoments since there is some logic required to determine the sign of some of the Euler angles. There are quite a few tests, though, that verify the functions by reconstructing the inertia matrix from the principal moments and rotation matrix of eigenvectors.

There is also an ipython notebook included that provides justification for a claim in the section about repeated principal moments. It is viewable here:

values.description:
Set the build_type to "Release" as this is the default value that we are using for Windows on the rest of the repositories.

I also enabled the test compilation. You can run them with `ctest` and they all passed.

Not sure if its related with this pull request but I had to disable the Windows Defender, otherwise I got compilation problems:

http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/turn-windows-defender-on-off#turn-windows-defender-on-off=windows-7
